metadata.title: Microfluidic Synthesis of Nanomaterials for Biomedical Applications

sections.text:
REVIEW

www.small-methods.com
Microfluidic Synthesis of Nanomaterials for Biomedical Applications
Li-Li Li, Xiaodong Li, and Hao Wang*
DOI: 10.1002/smtd.201700140
portability/wearability, higher sensitivity, lower cost, uniform nanostructural fabrication, lower energy consumption and highly integrated multifunctions, high-throughput, etc.[3c,4] Additionally, scaling effects lead to distinctly new phenomena, permitting new applications for synthesis of nanomaterials, such as high-speed serial processing and highdegree of parallelization.[4b]
The considerations of chemical synthesis of nanomaterials through microfluidic reactors are fundamentally in the requirements of highly efficient reactions, integrating the multiple steps in fabricating nanostructures, reproducible synthesis techniques, and
continuous flow to produce nanomaterials.[1a,6] When fabricating different nanomaterials on microfluidic devices, the design principles are the flexible generation of the components of the nanomaterials, well-controlled nanostructures, and the integration of screening their biofunctions or evaluating their biological effect with a high-throughput performance.[3a,7] In order to realize these desired results, the structural design of a device, its integration, and the layout of the functional parts are challenges in development and optimization.[8] In addition, microfluidic flows with typical microchannel hydrodynamic behavior play a significant role in microfluidic technologies.[9] Therein, two-phase flow systems are ubiquitous in processes, including in gas– liquid and liquid–liquid systems. In two-phase flows, the flow focus is on controlling the formation and coalescence of the droplets or bubbles.[9a] Also, the materials and design methods that are used for devices are crucial in harsh synthesis conditions.[10]
Here, we present recent developments in design principles of microfluidic synthesis systems, such as the controlled flow and packaging techniques. The basic synthesis methods for organic and inorganic nanomaterials through microfluidics are included. Next, the complex heterogeneous and multifunctional nanostructures fabricated using microfluidic platforms are summarized and discussed. Then, multifunctional nanomaterials and screening/verification of their biofunctions based on microfluidic systems through the high-throughput concept are reviewed. Finally, we provide the prospective opportunities for the development of microfluidics to realize the precisely controlled and highly efficient integrated synthesis of novel nanomaterials and nanostructures, which are difficult to achieve in standard batch modes/methods.
Increased attention has recently been paid to microfluidics, which display many advantages in the synthesis of nanomaterials. It deserves to be emphasized that microfluidics techniques include the chemical reaction, nanostructure assembly, modification of nanoparticles, and even evaluation of biomedical function. Here, the recent progress in the design principles of microfluidic systems for nanomaterials synthesis is summarized. In addition, microfluidics, on the microscale, expand the synthesis space, precisely controlled nanostructures, and high-throughput fabrication of multifunctional nanoparticles. Microfluidic platforms will open new avenues for the realization of custom-made complex nanostructures and nanomaterials in batch procedures for further biomedical applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Microfluidics are famous in advanced chemical, materials, and biomedical research, particularly in highly efficient chemical synthesis,[1] fabrication of controlled nanomaterials,[2] highthroughput biomarker analytic assay,[3] tissue-engineering scaffolds with cell seeding,[4] etc. For nanomaterials applications, microfluidics is excellent with respect to control over different characteristics, including control of multicomponent reactions and control over size, shape, composition, morphology, and size distribution of nanoparticles.[5] The progress of microfluidics regarding design concepts of chips or devices for fabrication of nanomaterials and the improved characteristics of nanomaterials produced on the microfluidic devices are major issues in understanding the microfluidics system for nanomaterial synthesis.
In comparison to classical and macroscopic systems that have been used for many decades, microfluidic devices offer advantages in shorter time to results, homogeneous reactions,

sections.heading: 2.1. General Principles
sections.text: The definition of the microfluidic synthesis system for a nanomaterial is that a set of fluidic unit operations are designed for the fabrication of the nanomaterial.[4b] The microfluidics design is aimed at miniaturization, integration, automation, and parallelization of nanomaterial synthesis processes. Microfluidic devices handle fluids with a volume typically in the range from microliters to picoliters.[9b] On the microscopic scale, the viscosity of the fluid plays a more significant role than inertia.[11] A significantly enhanced surface-area-to-volume ratio means there is more rapid heat and mass transfer than on a macroscopic scale.[12] The techniques used for microfluidics are classified into continuous flow and droplet-based flow with gas–liquid or liquid–liquid interfaces. In practical synthesized nanomaterial devices, two critical parameters should be carefully considered for design flexibility: precise manipulation of the hydrodynamic behavior and controlled addition of reagents and components.[1b,13]

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Microfluidic Flows
sections.text:
In microfluidics, fluids are controlled and manipulated on a length scale of micrometers. During the synthesis of nanomaterials, microfluidic flows are crucial for fabrication of nanoparticles in particular, due to the specific characteristics of laminar flow, short molecular-diffusion distance, and unparalleled capabilities of precise control and manipulation of the flow.[9a] Usually, microfluidic flows are divided into single-phase and two-phase flow. The primary parameters for single-phase flow focus on the properties of fluid and flow conditions. For two-phase flow, the situations are complex and rely on channel geometry (e.g., T-junctions, cross-flow, and flow-focusing, as shown in Figure 1), the properties of the two fluids, and the flow conditions.[9a,14] Compared to single-phase flow, two-phase flow exhibits various advantages in increasing the interfacial area, shortening the transfer distance, and enhancing the mixing efficiency. All the superior characteristics are attributed to the reduction of the mass-transfer limitations.[15] Two-phase-flow behavior in microfluidics requires interfacial interactions, including a liquid–liquid interfacial layer for droplets and a gas–liquid interfacial layer for bubbles. For controlled generation of droplets and bubbles, Zhao’s group developed a 3D valvebased controllable poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) nozzle for dynamic modulation of the droplet generation;[16] Also, Velankar’s group proposed a circuit model under controlled pressure for bubble generation.[17] In addition, microfluidics offers the possibility of fabricating complex emulsions, such as double or multiple emulsions, with different interfaces, liquid–liquid and gas–liquid. Overall, improved understanding of the hydrodynamic behavior for microfluidic flows is still needed for precisely controllable synthesis of nanomaterials.
Li-Li Li received her Ph.D. degree from Beijing University of Chemical Technology in 2012. Thereafter, she joined Prof. Hao Wang’s group at the National Center for Nanoscience and Technology as a post-doctoral fellow until 2015. She then worked for Prof. Hao Wang as an assistant research fellow from
2015 to 2016. In 2017, she became associate professor at the National Center for Nanoscience and Technology. Her research interests are designing and constructing functional supramolecular nanomaterials based on “in vivo self-assembly” technology for bacterial-infection therapy and diagnosis.
Li Xiaodong obtained his B.S. degree from Beijing Institute of Technology in 1992. Then, he obtained his Ph.D. degree from Beijing Institute of Technology in 2001. Thereafter, he held a lecturership in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology. In 2002, he became an associate
professor at Beijing Institute of Technology. His current research interests are in polymeric functional materials, the preparation and application of nanocomposite materials, and the catalysis and combustion of energetic materials.
Hao Wang obtained his B.S. and Ph.D. from the Department of Chemistry at Nankai University in 2000 and 2005, respectively. Afterward, he moved to Universät Würzburg as an Alexander von Humboldt fellow from 2005–2007. Then, he was a postdoctoral researcher in the Department of Molecular and Medical Pharmacology
at UCLA from 2007–2010. In 2011, he started his independent career as a “100 Talents Program of the CAS ” professor at the National Center for Nanoscience and Technology. His current research interests are developing “in vivo self-assembly” strategies for constructing functional biomaterials, studying their bio-effects, and further regulating their biological behavior for biomedical applications.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Packaging Techniques
sections.text: The fluidic connections between microreactors/microchannels and the macroscopic fluid system are called “packaging”. Conventional connection methods involve permanent integrated connections and nonpermanent modular connections, which can stand up to 17 MPa and 10 MPa, respectively.[2a] Also, the packaging schemes for microfluidics are combined with temperature controllers, optical fibers, valves, etc., for the integration of multiple functions during the synthesis of nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 3. Controlled Synthesis of Homogeneous Nanoparticles using Microfluidic Reactors
sections.text: The intrinsic advantages in microfluidic reactors can be described by way of microscale-dependent heat- and masstransfer processes.[1b] On this scale, microreactors need small reagent volumes and have a smaller footprint than macroscale reactors.[8] In chemical reactions, including organic and inorganic nanomaterials synthesis (Figure 2), the space–time reaction yield, i.e., the product formed per reactor time and volume, enables reactions in microfluidic reactors to be to sped up, compared with those in bulk reactions.[6a] Also, in some kinetically versus thermodynamically controlled reactions, the microscale channels would offer precise control over the local conditions and further enhance the reaction selectivity.[1a] Finally, the increased transfer efficiency, reduced energy consumption, and integration-saved reaction time etc. are all ascribed to the green credentials.[1]

sections.heading: 3.1. Organic Nanomaterials
sections.text:
For organic molecules, such as small molecules and polymers, the consequence of high heat-transfer and mass-transfer rates are well defined.[19] With respect to particulate organic nanomaterials, microfluidics can be combined with in-flow
analysis of the obtained particles. According to the control of the continuous flow, droplets or bubbles, micrometer- and nanometer-sized particles with narrow size distribution in single-phase or multiphase flows can be obtained.[20] Modulating the speed of laminar flow, which shows limited crosswise diffusion, the flow speeds are correlated to the particle size. Alternatively, the preceding highly efficient mixing of the flow leads to a well-controlled uniform size of the particles. Singlephase or two-phase reactors based on flow-speed control and interfacial interactions will all contribute to nanostructures and particle shapes.[6b] Of course, microfluidics is also well used for labeling or analysis of the particles during the synthesis process.[21] An example of good structural control under mild conditions is porous crystalline materials. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs), in continuous-flow microfluidics, have been obtained with high space–time yield of 703 kg m−3 day−1. The crystallinity and high porosity at room-temperature reaction for microfluidics were comparable to those in highertemperature reactions in bulk fabrications.[22] In a segmented flow (T-junction), size-controlled and morphologically homogeneous trinitroresorcinate (LTNR) particles were produced.[5a] Through 3D hydrodynamic flow focusing on single-layer microfluidics, size-tunable polymeric nanoparticles were synthesized.[18] In conclusion, continuous flow with single-phase or two-phase microfluidics is superior for controlled synthesis and fabrication of homogeneous nanomaterials, according to flow and phase control.

sections.heading: 3.2. Inorganic Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Inorganic nanomaterials can be classified as amorphous and crystalline nanoparticles. Their chemical and physical properties are normally strongly dependent on the size, shape, and structure of the particles. Thus, in conventional bulk reactions, rapid mixing of the injected precursors and surfactants, and a well-defined time–temperature profile are significant when considering the formation of nuclei, further affecting the nanoparticle growth. The monodispersity of

inorganic nanoparticles in the synthesis procedure is highly dependent on the reaction kinetics, the reaction fluids, their mixing, and the temperature. All of these are precisely controlled in microfluidics based on microscale characteristics. Controllable synthesis of colloidal semiconductor nanoparticles (e.g., CdSe), metal nanoparticles (e.g., Cu, Ag, Au), metal oxide nanoparticles (e.g., Fe2O3, SiO2, CePO4) and hybrid metal nanoparticles (e.g., polymer-stabilized metal nanoparticles) has been demonstrated.[2b,13,23] On a microfluidic reactor chip, a surfactant and nanoparticle seeds were controllably mixed in a Y-mixer. The promoted growth of seeds led to highly monodisperse copper nanoparticles with a critical size of 135.6 ± 11.4 nm.[24] Khan and Duraiswamy improved the synthesis method with the concept of multiphase mass transfer to overcome the gas-evolution problem for synthesis of ultrasmall gold nanorods.[25] Moreover, some inorganic nanoparticles should be synthesized at high temperatures. For improved capillary-based droplet reactors, the synthesis of Ag, TiO2, and CdSe at high temperatures was performed, and the continuous reaction process was well-controlled with exceptional stability.[26]
3.3. Precisely Controlled Complex Nanostructures based on Microfluidics
Besides the demands for homogeneity, including in size, shape, and uniform distribution, controllable nanostructures are another significant consideration.[2a,27] According to the improved design of microfluidic structures and flows, various complex nanostructures have been achieved, such as core–shell nanoparticles, nanogels with controlled pore-size, Janus particles, and other complex vesicles.[28] For instance, based on droplet microfluidics, polymeric particles with complex internal structures and porosity have been obtained by templating from liquid-crystalline droplets.[29] Bipolar, radial, axial, and pre-radial templates have contributed to spindleshaped, spherical, spherocylindrical, and tear-shaped polymeric particles with anisotropic polymer networks (Figure 3A). With a well-controlled capillary microfluidic device and oil-inwater (O/W) single emulsions, monodisperse azopolymeric microspheres with raspberry-like and acorn-like shaped azoparticles have been generated.[30] In addition, surface-decorated inorganic nanoparticles or nanoparticles encoded by quantum dots (QDs) can be achieved for devices. For example, through double-emulsion templates generated in capillary microfluidics, Weitz and co-workers developed a new approach for the fabrication of anisotropic magnetic-barcode nanoparticles.[31] The particles were exhibited Janus characteristics with separate cores or a Janus core (Figure 3B). A microfluidic chip with flexible characteristics was also suitable for the synthesis and separation of magnetite-decorated gold nanoparticles.[32] The self-assembly of gelatin and the subsequent chemical crosslinking of the nanogel with quantum dots (QDs) dispersed inside were continuously carried out in a controlled manner.[33] Poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)–acrylate polymer beads encoded with 24 distinct ratios of two lanthanide nanophosphors were synthesized by automated microfluidics.[34] Furthermore, on the microfluidic, the self-assembled polymers, with tunable size and surface coating, are easily obtained. For example, through a tubing method, size-controlled poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA) nanoparticles with a size

sections.heading: 3.4. Multifunctional Nanoparticles Fabricating through the High-Throughput Microfluidic Platform
sections.text:
In biological applications, screening is normally useful for identifying the relationship between structures/components/shape/size with their biofunctions. However, methods for the fabrication of a library of nanomaterials in the bulk suffer from high consumption of materials, time, and manpower. Meanwhile, the parallelization of nanomaterials is hard to control. Combining integrated microfluidics with a high degree of automation presents many advantages in high-throughput biological evaluation of nanomaterials. Recently improved integrated microfluidics provide the high possibility of biological applications, such as screening of delivered nanodrugs and nanoprobes.[3b,7] Firstly, the novel design of microfluidic devices provides us with highthroughput parallel fabrication of a nanomaterials library. For example, in co-flow geometry, the inner fluid flow has been set inside the inner cylindrical capillary: the inner and outer fluids were pumped together in the same direction, resulting in 3D coaxial flow (Figure 4A). It is worth mentioning that in this system, the Reynolds number (Re) can be modulated, to vary from 10 to 200. This high-throughput microfluidic platform leads to the synthesis of homo geneous nanoparticles with tunable properties.[37] In addition, with regard to supramolecular assemblies of nanomaterials, multi-component modulation can be achieved on a digital dual-core microplatform.[7] The nanoassemblies were able to be programmed with a broad structural and functional diversity by altering the mixing ratios of the molecular building blocks in different injected channels (Figure 4B). In this approach, over 103 different nanoparticles have been synthesized in a parallel form. By integrating the evaluation on cells, an improved high-throughput platform was capable for formulating and screening multifunctional nanoparticles for gene-delivery efficiency (Figure 5).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: The continuous synthesis of nanomaterials by microfluidics has been greatly improved at the proof-of-concept stage. However, further considerations are the robust, well-integrated, scalable and automatic properties of different devices. For good control of synthesis of nanomaterials with designed nanostructures, a better understanding of the flows and the fluid hydrodynamics are a priority and thus highly important. Moreover, further systems should also be integrated, high-throughput platforms for synthesis of nanomaterials, material evaluation, and biofunction screening. In conclusion, microfluidic devices have a number of beneficial features for the fabrication of nanomaterials. Although further studies are still needed, chemists and physicists all have faith in the broad prospects of microfluidics for synthesis of nanomaterials.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/smtd.201700140 portability/wearability, higher sensitivity, lower cost, uniform nanostructural fabrication, lower energy consumption and highly integrated multifunctions, high-throughput, etc.[3c,4] Additionally, scaling effects lead to distinctly new phenomena, permitting new applications for synthesis of nanomaterials, such as high-speed serial processing and highdegree of parallelization.[4b] The considerations of chemical synthesis of nanomaterials through microfluidic reactors are fundamentally in the requirements of highly efficient reactions, integrating the multiple steps in fabricating nanostructures, reproducible synthesis techniques, and continuous flow to produce nanomaterials.[1a,6] When fabricating different nanomaterials on microfluidic devices, the design principles are the flexible generation of the components of the nanomaterials, well-controlled nanostructures, and the integration of screening their biofunctions or evaluating their biological effect with a high-throughput performance.[3a,7] In order to realize these desired results, the structural design of a device, its integration, and the layout of the functional parts are challenges in development and optimization.[8] In addition, microfluidic flows with typical microchannel hydrodynamic behavior play a significant role in microfluidic technologies.[9] Therein, two-phase flow systems are ubiquitous in processes, including in gas– liquid and liquid–liquid systems. In two-phase flows, the flow focus is on controlling the formation and coalescence of the droplets or bubbles.[9a] Also, the materials and design methods that are used for devices are crucial in harsh synthesis conditions.[10] Here, we present recent developments in design principles of microfluidic synthesis systems, such as the controlled flow and packaging techniques. The basic synthesis methods for organic and inorganic nanomaterials through microfluidics are included. Next, the complex heterogeneous and multifunctional nanostructures fabricated using microfluidic platforms are summarized and discussed. Then, multifunctional nanomaterials and screening/verification of their biofunctions based on microfluidic systems through the high-throughput concept are reviewed. Finally, we provide the prospective opportunities for the development of microfluidics to realize the precisely controlled and highly efficient integrated synthesis of novel nanomaterials and nanostructures, which are difficult to achieve in standard batch modes/methods. Increased attention has recently been paid to microfluidics, which display many advantages in the synthesis of nanomaterials. It deserves to be emphasized that microfluidics techniques include the chemical reaction, nanostructure assembly, modification of nanoparticles, and even evaluation of biomedical function. Here, the recent progress in the design principles of microfluidic systems for nanomaterials synthesis is summarized. In addition, microfluidics, on the microscale, expand the synthesis space, precisely controlled nanostructures, and high-throughput fabrication of multifunctional nanoparticles. Microfluidic platforms will open new avenues for the realization of custom-made complex nanostructures and nanomaterials in batch procedures for further biomedical applications. Microfluidics
